categories.heading: A. Core concepts
categories.descriptionHtml: These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.

entries.title: Ethotechnics
entries.bodyHtml: The craft of designing systems that can behave morally. Where ethics asks “What should I do?” and systems theory asks “How does it behave?”, Ethotechnics asks: How can it behave well? Moral behavior is treated as an architectural capability, not a personal virtue.
examples: A hospital release board adds Ethotechnic stop-checks before deploying triage updates to keep clinicians in control.

entries.title: Moral Behavior (of Systems)
entries.bodyHtml: Observable patterns of system behavior that prevent harm, share burden fairly, and keep people contestable and whole. Moral behavior is evaluated through MPIs such as time-to-halt, reversibility, and fair burden distribution—not by stated intent.
examples: A payments platform throttles recommendations when fraud signals spike until human reviewers clear the backlog.

entries.title: Ethical Load Path
entries.bodyHtml: The route moral responsibility travels through a system—across automation, humans, and institutions. A clear ethical load path shows who can stop, reverse, or repair harm at each stage, linking design authority, oversight horizons, and the repair log.
examples: A transit authority publishes who can halt automated dispatch at each escalation step, including night-shift supervisors.

entries.title: Ethotechnic Audit
entries.bodyHtml: A structured assessment of a system’s capacity to stop harm, reverse it, distribute burden fairly, remain contestable, and enable accountability. Audits surface where stopability or reversibility fail and guide concrete remediation steps.
examples: A platform review board runs an Ethotechnic audit after an outage to trace who could have halted or reversed the release.

entries.title: Conviviality
entries.bodyHtml: The degree to which tools and institutions expand people’s agency, cooperation, and right of refusal instead of enclosing them. Convivial systems keep permission surfaces wide and make opting out safe, so people can shape the service without being consumed by it.
examples: A mutual aid platform lets neighbors pause notifications or change delivery preferences without losing access to support.

entries.title: Ethotechnic Maturity
entries.bodyHtml: A developmental scale describing how fully a system embodies Ethotechnic capabilities. Early maturity focuses on stopping acute harms; later stages add graceful degradation, contestability, and regular care retrospectives. The highest level treats ethics as continuous operations, with published SLJs and funded maintenance practice.
examples: A rail operator publishes service-level justice metrics and funds quarterly pause drills to keep reversibility fresh.

categories.heading: B. Failure modes (why Ethotechnics exists)
categories.descriptionHtml: Common patterns where responsibility dissolves and harm accelerates.

entries.title: Moral Latency
entries.bodyHtml: The delay between harm occurring and the system recognizing it. Automated systems create harms faster than human oversight can register, demanding velocity friction and ethical interrupts.
examples: A clinic triage chatbot keeps routing people while harm reports queue for hours, hiding the moral latency from clinicians.

entries.title: Accountability Diffusion
entries.bodyHtml: Responsibility dissolves across teams, tools, and incentives until no one can intervene. A defining pattern of modern institutions and a direct threat to clear design authority.
examples: A support ticket bounces between a vendor and a hospital compliance team with no one empowered to pause the rollout.

entries.title: Extraction
entries.bodyHtml: When a system pulls value—data, attention, labor, or social capital—without returning care, consent, or repair. Extraction hides true costs through externalization and steep burden gradients, hollowing trust.
examples: A data-labeling program offloads unpaid overnight verification to gig workers while the platform reports clean metrics.

entries.title: Extraction by Endurance
entries.bodyHtml: Systems that depend on workers or users absorbing fragility through burnout, emotional labor, or unpaid cognitive work—often mislabeled as “resilience.” Ethotechnic practice aims to invert this burden with fair burden distribution.

entries.title: Drift (System Drift)
entries.bodyHtml: The natural tendency of systems to externalize harm over time unless constrained by protective friction and moral performance indicators.

entries.title: Externalization
entries.bodyHtml:
Pushing risk, cost, or harm onto other teams, communities, or the future so metrics look clean. Externalization shows up as pollution, shadow labor, or brittle dependencies that live outside audits.

Ethotechnics counters it with oversight horizons, MPIs, and transparent repair logs.

entries.title: Brittleness
entries.bodyHtml: When a system shatters under real-world variance—unexpected inputs, refusals, or edge cases—forcing humans to absorb impact. Brittleness signals missing soft edges, thin graceful degradation, and poor refusal tolerance.
examples: A flight booking bot fails on hyphenated surnames, forcing airport agents to override tickets at the counter.

entries.title: Optimization Myopia
entries.bodyHtml: Metric-chasing that narrows attention to throughput or growth while ignoring MPIs. Myopic optimization erodes contestability, raises failure load, and often fuels extraction.

entries.title: Precision Laundering
entries.bodyHtml: Using detailed metrics or probabilistic scores to disguise inequity as objectivity. Precision laundering hides burden gradients and externalization behind statistical gloss, undermining explainability for accountability.

entries.title: Compliance Collapse
entries.bodyHtml: When rigid policy checklists replace judgment, causing teams to follow rules while harm worsens. Compliance collapses occur when design authority is weak and contestability is low, leaving no path to pause or repair.

categories.heading: C. Ethotechnic capabilities (what systems must be able to do)
categories.descriptionHtml: Design requirements that keep people safe when systems scale.

entries.title: Stopability
entries.bodyHtml: A system’s ability to halt harmful processes quickly and automatically—without requiring heroism or escalation.

entries.title: Reversibility
entries.bodyHtml: Critical actions can be undone. Damage is not permanent by default, and time-to-restore stays low.

entries.title: Fair Burden Distribution
entries.bodyHtml: Failures do not fall hardest on the most vulnerable. Burden is treated as a design variable and measured via the user burden ratio.

entries.title: Contestability
entries.bodyHtml: People affected by system decisions can challenge, change, or overturn them—and win. Contestability combines permission surface and appeal passage rate.

entries.title: Explainability for Accountability
entries.bodyHtml: Explanations that are actionable, not decorative. They reveal who made a decision and how it can be corrected, enabling contestability and audits.

entries.title: Human Refusal-Tolerance
entries.bodyHtml: The system remains usable when people opt out, are confused, make mistakes, or withdraw cooperation. Refusal tolerance prevents extraction by endurance by ensuring refusals do not silently convert into extra unpaid work.

entries.title: Graceful Degradation
entries.bodyHtml: The system sheds features or load in controlled stages while keeping people safe. Graceful degradation prioritizes care floor guarantees, maintains stopability, and keeps time-to-restore low.

entries.title: Soft Edges
entries.bodyHtml: Boundary conditions designed to cushion people instead of penalizing them—graduated responses, warnings before lockouts, and reversible defaults. Soft edges reduce failure load and guard against brittleness.

categories.heading: D. System states & architectures
categories.descriptionHtml: Operational postures that determine how harm is absorbed—or amplified.

entries.title: Fail-Safe Mode
entries.bodyHtml: The system defaults to the safest possible behavior when uncertain, prioritizing stopability.

entries.title: Fail-Open Mode
entries.bodyHtml: The system defaults to permissiveness under failure—sometimes necessary, sometimes dangerous. Must be paired with velocity friction.

entries.title: Fail-Silent Mode
entries.bodyHtml: A harmful state where systems fail without signaling it; the worst possible form of failure because it hides moral latency.

entries.title: Crumple Zone / Human-as-Crumple-Zone
entries.bodyHtml: Originally: machines absorb force so people survive. Digitally: people absorb system failures so machines stay smooth. Ethotechnics reverses this direction of impact.

entries.title: Harm Visibility
entries.bodyHtml: How plainly a system exposes the human impact of its decisions in real time. High harm visibility pairs logs, narratives, and alerts so oversight horizons extend beyond dashboards and ethical interrupts trigger on lived effects, not just technical anomalies.

entries.title: Dead Zones / Moral Dead Zones
entries.bodyHtml: Places in a system where harm occurs but no one can see, trace, or intervene. Closing dead zones is a goal of oversight horizons.

entries.title: Escalation Horizon
entries.bodyHtml: The predefined point where automated control must yield to human judgment because risk, ambiguity, or moral latency is rising. Escalation horizons activate ethical interrupts and route cases to accountable stewards before crossing an irreversible boundary.

entries.title: Interaction Surface
entries.bodyHtml: The moments, interfaces, and channels where people experience system decisions and can intervene. Mapping the interaction surface reveals where to place dignity friction, widen the permission surface, and detect dead-user zones.

entries.title: Maintenance Window
entries.bodyHtml:
A scheduled calm state where teams intentionally slow or stop throughput so inspections, upgrades, and rehearsals can happen without crisis pressure. Maintenance windows make stopability routine instead of reactive.

Each window is negotiated with the people impacted, includes published service guarantees, and documents which safeguards were tested so unfinished work rolls into the shared repair log.

entries.title: Care Retrospective
entries.bodyHtml:
A facilitated reflection held while the system is still in a warning band to examine how maintenance load, emotional labor, and unresolved incidents are accumulating. Care retrospectives combine telemetry with frontline testimony.

They redistribute responsibilities before burnout or harm escalates, triggering new maintenance windows or policy fixes when the team cannot keep absorbing risk.

entries.title: Repair Log
entries.bodyHtml:
A living record of every mitigation, decision, and resource commitment made after a fault. Repair logs make accountability legible by linking people harmed, who intervened, and what evidence was used.

They inform future care retrospectives, power audits, and service-level reports so follow-up work is traceable and burden does not drift back to the same communities.

categories.heading: E. Human limits & experience
categories.descriptionHtml: Design that honors the limits of human time, cognition, and care.

entries.title: Finitude
entries.bodyHtml: The bodily, cognitive, emotional, and temporal limits all humans share. Ethotechnics treats finitude as a design input, not an inconvenience.

entries.title: Cognitive Saturation Point
entries.bodyHtml: The load level at which human decision quality collapses—too many alerts, too little time, or excessive context switching. Ethotechnic design lowers saturation by adding velocity friction, simplifying interaction surfaces, and staffing to real maintenance metabolism.

entries.title: Compassion Bandwidth
entries.bodyHtml: The sustainable amount of emotional labor a system asks of people—care teams, moderators, frontline staff, or users. When compassion bandwidth is exceeded, dread work grows and extraction by endurance sets in.

entries.title: Administrative Shame
entries.bodyHtml: The feeling of being personally at fault for harms produced by system design. Often a signal that moral overhead is too high.

entries.title: Dread Work
entries.bodyHtml: Tasks people avoid because the system punishes mistakes or withholds relief. Dread work signals missing soft edges, low contestability, and declining compassion bandwidth.

entries.title: Refusal Budget
entries.bodyHtml: The number of times a person can decline, pause, or question a request without retaliation. Healthy refusal budgets, backed by refusal tolerance and rights of exit, prevent coercion and surface heat maps of refusal.

categories.heading: F. Burden & load
categories.descriptionHtml: How systems allocate the cost of operation or failure.

entries.title: Burden Distribution
entries.bodyHtml: How a system allocates the cost of operation or failure—time, attention, stress, and emotional labor.

entries.title: Burden Gradient
entries.bodyHtml:
The slope of effort and risk across roles or communities. A steep burden gradient means those with the least power carry the heaviest operational load while decision-makers feel little friction.

Mapping the gradient exposes where to redistribute work through fair burden distribution and reduce moral overhead.

entries.title: Failure Load
entries.bodyHtml: The amount of harm generated when the system fails. Ethotechnics seeks low-failure-load architectures supported by graceful degradation.

entries.title: Burden Transfer Event
entries.bodyHtml: Moments when system failure pushes labor onto humans, often triggering moral overhead.

entries.title: Maintenance Metabolism
entries.bodyHtml:
The baseline flow of upkeep—patching, cleaning, rehearsing, and caring—that keeps a service alive when nothing is on fire. Healthy maintenance metabolism is budgeted, scheduled, and shared rather than squeezed between crises.

Falling below it signals rising maintenance debt and invites maintenance windows before fragility compounds.

entries.title: Maintenance Debt
entries.bodyHtml:
Accumulated obligations from skipping basic upkeep. The interest is paid in slower recovery, brittle systems, and people burning out to keep things running.

Paying it down requires restoring the maintenance metabolism, scheduling maintenance windows, and tracking work in the repair log.

entries.title: Moral Overhead
entries.bodyHtml: Extra work users or operators must do to behave ethically within a bad system.

entries.title: Asymmetric Sustaining
entries.bodyHtml:
When one group continually absorbs the toil of keeping a system alive so another group can move fast or claim success. It often hides behind gratitude for “resilience” while masking extraction.

Ethotechnic practice flattens this by lowering the burden gradient and designing for stopability so resilience is institutional, not personal.

entries.title: Fragility Subsidy
entries.bodyHtml: The unpaid labor, vigilance, or emotional buffering people contribute to keep brittle systems functioning. Fragility subsidies hide true costs, inflate success metrics, and deepen asymmetric sustaining.

entries.title: Burden Index
entries.bodyHtml:
A composite measure of how much effort, time, and emotional labor people expend to use or recover from a system.

Inputs include the user burden ratio, human substitution index, and failure load; rising scores signal extraction or asymmetric sustaining.

categories.heading: G. Measures & indicators
categories.descriptionHtml: Metrics that track moral performance across systems.

entries.title: Moral Performance Indicators (MPIs)
entries.bodyHtml: Key metrics that show a system’s ethical functioning: time-to-halt (TTH), reversibility rate, appeal success rate, burden ratios, and more. MPIs complement traditional KPIs by tracking how safely and fairly a system operates, not just how fast it grows.

entries.title: Service-Level Indicators of Justice (SLJs)
entries.bodyHtml: Operational metrics tied directly to fairness, safety, and dignity. SLJs should sit alongside uptime and latency commitments.

entries.title: Institutional Metabolism Mapping
entries.bodyHtml:
A diagnostic mapping of where energy, care, time, and money circulate inside an institution. It visualizes maintenance metabolism, burden gradients, and points of extraction.

Teams use the map to set SLJs, redesign roles, and decide where to invest new maintenance windows.

entries.title: Time-to-Halt (TTH)
entries.bodyHtml: Seconds between a harmful process beginning and the system stopping it—an essential complement to stopability.

entries.title: Time-to-Restore (TTR)
entries.bodyHtml: How long it takes to reverse harm and return a person to their prior state. Low TTR is a signal of effective reversibility.

entries.title: Appeal Passage Rate
entries.bodyHtml: The percentage of appeals resolved in favor of the user, a leading indicator of true contestability.

entries.title: Irreversibility Index
entries.bodyHtml: The share of system actions that cannot be undone. Aim to keep this as low as possible through reversibility and graceful degradation.

entries.title: User Burden Ratio
entries.bodyHtml: How much work a user must perform to correct or navigate system errors. This metric feeds directly into fair burden distribution.

entries.title: Human Substitution Index
entries.bodyHtml: A measure of how often humans must step in to compensate for system shortcomings—manual reviews, ad-hoc patches, or empathy work. A rising index exposes heroism-dependent systems and motivates investment in graceful degradation.

entries.title: Moral Debt
entries.bodyHtml: The accumulated harm a system has caused but not repaired. Moral debt accrues interest as moral latency grows and people lose trust; it is paid down through pathways to restitution, transparent repair logs, and lowered time-to-restore.

entries.title: Signal Credibility
entries.bodyHtml:
The trustworthiness of alerts, metrics, and reports used to govern a system.

High signal credibility pairs transparent sampling, explainability for accountability, and human testimony so warnings trigger action instead of alert fatigue or dismissal.

categories.heading: H. Governance & power
categories.descriptionHtml: Structures that determine who sets moral boundaries and who can intervene.

entries.title: Design Authority
entries.bodyHtml: The accountable power to set moral constraints, choose safeguards, and fund enforcement. Clear design authority aligns incentives, protects contestability, and prevents accountability diffusion.

entries.title: Oversight Horizon
entries.bodyHtml: The distance regulators, auditors, or affected communities can see into a system’s decisions and their effects. Extending the horizon—through harm visibility, traceable models, and shared repair logs—shrinks dead zones.

entries.title: Permission Surface
entries.bodyHtml: What users can do without institutional approval — a measure of autonomy and a prerequisite for contestability.

entries.title: Right of Exit
entries.bodyHtml: The ability to leave a system without ruinous cost or retaliation. A foundational condition for ethical participation.

entries.title: Externalized Harm Channels
entries.bodyHtml: The pathways an institution uses to push risk or cleanup onto others: contractors, users, bystanders, or future teams. Mapping these channels exposes externalization and informs fair burden distribution.

entries.title: Stewardship Window
entries.bodyHtml:
A negotiated period where teams pause growth work to focus on care, maintenance, and accountability.

Stewardship windows bundle maintenance windows, publish SLJs for the pause, and commit to closing items in the repair log before resuming throughput.

categories.heading: I. Friction & flow
categories.descriptionHtml: Designing intentional friction that protects people while keeping harm contained.

entries.title: Protective Friction
entries.bodyHtml: Friction that slows harmful processes and keeps moral latency within safe bounds.

entries.title: Punitive Friction
entries.bodyHtml: Friction that punishes users—often hidden in bureaucratic loops. Signals extraction by endurance.

entries.title: Dignity Friction
entries.bodyHtml: Friction that preserves autonomy, such as double checks on irreversible actions.

entries.title: Velocity Friction
entries.bodyHtml: Friction added specifically to prevent runaway system behaviors. Often implemented through ethical interrupts.

entries.title: Safety Valve
entries.bodyHtml:
A deliberate release point that lets people slow, pause, or reroute automation before harm compounds.

Safety valves pair stopability with dignity friction so high-stakes flows default to reversible states and route to humans without penalty.

entries.title: Consent Journey
entries.bodyHtml:
The sequenced touchpoints where a person learns what a system will do, grants or denies permission, and can revise that choice over time.

Strong consent journeys use anticipatory consent, visible permission surfaces, and healthy refusal budgets so pausing or exiting does not jeopardize access or care.

entries.title: Humane Friction
entries.bodyHtml: The calibrated blend of protective, dignity, and velocity frictions.

entries.title: Frictionless Harm
entries.bodyHtml: Harms that spread unchecked because safeguards or pauses were stripped away. Frictionless harm is the inverse of protective friction; it appears when velocity friction and dignity friction are absent.

categories.heading: J. Decision states & edges
categories.descriptionHtml: Where and how decisions flip from reversible to permanent.

entries.title: Decision Edge
entries.bodyHtml: The precise moment when a choice shifts from reversible to consequential. Making the decision edge visible enables dignity friction, clearer consent, and routing to ethical interrupts when risk spikes.

entries.title: Critical Action
entries.bodyHtml: Any system action that meaningfully alters a person’s status, access, or trajectory. Critical actions require dignity friction.

entries.title: Irreversible Boundary
entries.bodyHtml: A threshold the system cannot automatically undo—account closures, public releases, or data publication. Crossing it demands heightened contestability, audited explanations, and explicit time-to-restore plans.

entries.title: Ethical Interrupts
entries.bodyHtml: Automatic system-level halts triggered by anomalies or harm indicators. Ethical interrupts operationalize stopability.

categories.heading: K. System patterns & anti-patterns
categories.descriptionHtml: Recurring structures that demand Ethotechnic countermeasures.

entries.title: Heroism-Dependent Systems
entries.bodyHtml: Systems that rely on extraordinary effort, unpaid care, or silent sacrifice to function. They mask poor stopability and high failure load.

entries.title: Empathy Surrogacy
entries.bodyHtml: Simulated warmth—chatbots, scripted apologies, tone guidelines—used to mask structural harm or delay fixes. Empathy surrogacy diverts attention from repair and weakens contestability by substituting sentiment for remedy.

entries.title: Error Cascades
entries.bodyHtml: Small automated mistakes that amplify across the system. Prevented through ethical interrupts and SLJs.

entries.title: Invisible Fallbacks
entries.bodyHtml: Hidden behaviors that appear under stress—shadow queues, silent throttling, or undocumented overrides. Invisible fallbacks obscure ethical load paths and should be surfaced through graceful rollback lanes and rehearsed in maintenance windows.

entries.title: Dead-User Zones
entries.bodyHtml: Places where people affected by decisions cannot contest, appeal, or exit—opaque rankings, automated bans, or unmoderated queues. Closing dead-user zones requires widening the permission surface and raising appeal passage rates.

entries.title: Moral Lock-In
entries.bodyHtml: When harmful defaults become entrenched through dependencies, network effects, or contracts that block reform. Moral lock-in is prevented by moral feature gating, contestability, and vigilant moral drift control.

categories.heading: L. Future concepts / research areas
categories.descriptionHtml: These placeholders signal Ethotechnics as an evolving field.

entries.title: Moral Drift Control
entries.bodyHtml: Instrumentation and controls that detect when system behavior drifts from ethical baselines—through MPIs or user testimony—and automatically trigger interrupts or design changes.

entries.title: Structural Gentleness Coefficients
entries.bodyHtml: Measures of how forgiving an infrastructure is to human variance: error tolerance, recovery time, and soft edges. Higher coefficients correlate with lower failure load and safer degradation.

entries.title: Burden Elasticity
entries.bodyHtml: How effort and risk stretch or rebound between actors when conditions change. Mapping burden elasticity alongside the burden gradient prevents crises from snapping back onto the least powerful.

entries.title: Care Redundancy
entries.bodyHtml: Overlapping care pathways—humans, automation, and policy—that ensure someone is caught when another safeguard fails. Care redundancy pairs with graceful degradation to keep failure load low.

entries.title: Meta-Contestability
entries.bodyHtml: Mechanisms that let people challenge not just outcomes but the rules of challenge themselves—who may appeal, what evidence counts, and who sits on review panels. Meta-contestability keeps contestability from ossifying.

entries.title: User-State Modeling for Harm Prevention
entries.bodyHtml: Inferring user states—fatigue, distress, inattention—to adapt pacing, add protective friction, or route to humans before harm compounds. Models must respect anticipatory consent and avoid new burden transfers.

entries.title: Design for Ethical Latency
entries.bodyHtml: Designing for unavoidable delay between action and ethical evaluation by staging risky steps, adding velocity friction, or seeking care floor guarantees while fuller review occurs.

entries.title: Distributed Accountability Protocols
entries.bodyHtml: Coordination methods that keep responsibility legible across teams and automation: shared playbooks, auditable handoffs, and repair logs. Protocols prevent accountability diffusion when work moves.

entries.title: Ethotechnic Failure Taxonomy
entries.bodyHtml: A common vocabulary for classifying moral failure modes—optimization myopia, brittleness, extraction, and more—so incidents can be compared, learned from, and prevented.

entries.title: Adaptive Refusal Pathways
entries.bodyHtml: Dynamic flows that reroute tasks when someone pauses or declines, preserving context and avoiding retaliation. Adaptive pathways extend refusal budgets and strengthen refusal tolerance.

entries.title: Aftercare Automation
entries.bodyHtml: Automated follow-up that checks on impacted people after incidents, schedules remedies, and prompts humans to close the loop. Done well, it lowers moral debt without creating new moral overhead.

entries.title: Alignment Dividend
entries.bodyHtml: The measurable upside—trust, retention, safety—generated when systems align with human values. Tracking the dividend builds the business case for sustained investment in MPIs and maintenance metabolism.

entries.title: Ambiguity Budgets
entries.bodyHtml: Explicit allowances for uncertainty that prevent premature automation or brittle enforcement. Ambiguity budgets reserve time, human review, or maintenance windows until context is sufficient.

entries.title: Anticipatory Consent
entries.bodyHtml: Consent models that preview future data uses and let people pre-approve, defer, or block them. Anticipatory consent supports rights of exit and counters precision laundering of unclear terms.

entries.title: Boundary of Acceptable Harm
entries.bodyHtml: Dynamic thresholds defining when moral risk exceeds the system’s mandate and operations must halt or escalate. Boundaries are tied to SLJs and enforced through ethical circuit breakers.

entries.title: Care Floor Guarantees
entries.bodyHtml: Baseline commitments a service maintains even during outages or crises—live support, data export, or safe defaults. Care floors protect users when graceful degradation activates.

entries.title: Compassion Telemetry
entries.bodyHtml: Signals that show whether interactions feel humane—response tone, wait times during distress, quality of follow-up. Compassion telemetry complements technical metrics to protect compassion bandwidth.

entries.title: Conflict Observability
entries.bodyHtml: Instrumentation that makes value conflicts visible in logs and dashboards before they erupt—flagging when SLJs trade off against throughput or when appeals spike. High observability enables earlier moral drift control.

entries.title: Counter-Abuse Guardrails
entries.bodyHtml: Limits that prevent tools from being repurposed for harassment, exploitation, or coercion—rate limits, anomaly detection, and human override lanes tuned for abuse scenarios.

entries.title: Crisis Rehearsal Loops
entries.bodyHtml: Regular drills that stress-test moral responses, not just uptime. They practice ethical interrupts, validate care floors, and update repair logs with lessons.

entries.title: Data Dignity Budgets
entries.bodyHtml: Caps on data collection and use that respect personhood and context, not just legal checkbox consent. Budgets align with anticipatory consent and guard against extraction.

entries.title: Decision Debt Ledger
entries.bodyHtml: A register of deferred decisions and their moral interest, reviewed before debt compounds into harm. The ledger feeds maintenance windows and informs MPIs.

entries.title: Downstream Equity Buffers
entries.bodyHtml: Design slack that absorbs variance so marginalized groups do not pay first or most when errors occur. Buffers include staggered rollouts, rollback lanes, and targeted support funds.

entries.title: Ethical Circuit Breakers
entries.bodyHtml: Automated stops that trip when moral risk indicators cross predefined set points—surges in appeals, bias metrics, or moral debt. They are the safety counterpart to financial circuit breakers.

entries.title: Ethical Load Testing
entries.bodyHtml: Deliberate exercises that probe how systems behave under moral stress—simulated harassment, mass appeals, or outage scenarios—to validate ethical circuit breakers and care floors.

entries.title: Exhaustion Triggers
entries.bodyHtml: Signals that detect operator or user fatigue—error streaks, long queues, late-night decisions—and automatically slow, pause, or hand off flows before mistakes multiply. Triggers protect compassion bandwidth.

entries.title: Friction Budgets
entries.bodyHtml: Planned allocations of protective and dignity frictions across journeys to balance safety with usability, rather than defaulting to speed.

entries.title: Graceful Rollback Lanes
entries.bodyHtml: Prepared routes to revert harmful decisions while preserving dignity, evidence, and service continuity. Rollback lanes keep irreversibility indices low and shorten time-to-restore.

entries.title: Harm Amnesty Windows
entries.bodyHtml: Time-boxed periods where people can report or reverse harmful actions without penalty, encouraging disclosure and faster repair. Amnesty windows often follow rehearsal loops or incidents.

entries.title: Heat Maps of Refusal
entries.bodyHtml: Visualizations showing where users opt out, churn, or appeal—revealing coercion hotspots early. Heat maps help tune refusal budgets and redesign interaction surfaces.

entries.title: Human Override Lanes
entries.bodyHtml: Guaranteed routes for human judgment to supersede automation when stakes are high or context is missing. Override lanes accompany ethical interrupts and require clear ethical load paths.

entries.title: Incident Memory Chains
entries.bodyHtml: Linked records that keep lessons from past incidents attached to similar workflows so knowledge stays actionable. Memory chains inform ethical load tests and prevent moral lock-in on bad patterns.

entries.title: Moral Dry Runs
entries.bodyHtml: Pre-launch walkthroughs that simulate ethical dilemmas to harden designs before they reach the public. Dry runs test circuit breakers, rollback lanes, and documentation.

entries.title: Moral Feature Gating
entries.bodyHtml: Controls that block feature launch until moral readiness criteria—oversight plans, contestability pathways, and care floors—are met.

entries.title: Pathways to Restitution
entries.bodyHtml: Documented steps a system must take to repair harm: acknowledgement, remedy, verification, and follow-up. Pathways reduce moral debt and belong in the repair log.

entries.title: Refusal-Aware Routing
entries.bodyHtml: Routing logic that accounts for who can decline tasks and ensures refusals are respected without retaliation or silent penalization. It preserves refusal budgets and keeps workflows humane.

entries.title: Relief Invariants
entries.bodyHtml: Assurances that regardless of pathway, people can access relief with predictable effort and support. Relief invariants are tested in crisis rehearsals and anchored by care floors.

entries.title: Repair Quorums
entries.bodyHtml: Minimum participation rules for authorizing fixes so impacted communities have a seat in deciding remedies. Repair quorums counter accountability diffusion and legitimize restitution.

entries.title: Rest Cycle Enforcement
entries.bodyHtml: Built-in mechanisms that enforce rest and recovery—rotation policies, cooldown timers, enforced downtime—so fatigue does not translate into harm. Enforcement protects maintenance metabolism and compassion bandwidth.

categories.heading: M. Foundational Ethotechnic principles
categories.descriptionHtml: Axioms that will eventually define the discipline. Full definitions are in development.

entries.title: The Conservancy Principle
entries.bodyHtml: Designers steward human dignity and collective resources; they must leave systems safer and more reparable than they found them. Conservancy prioritizes repair, stopability, and minimizing moral debt.

entries.title: The Burden Inversion Rule
entries.bodyHtml: When harm occurs, the system shoulders effort before the person harmed does. Burden inversion lowers the user burden ratio and demands rapid restoration.

entries.title: The Stop-Before-Explain Rule
entries.bodyHtml: Halt harmful behavior first, then justify or refine it. Systems must trigger ethical interrupts before offering explanations, preserving reversibility.

entries.title: The Maintenance Doctrine
entries.bodyHtml: Ethical performance depends on continuous upkeep—funded maintenance metabolism, scheduled maintenance windows, and transparent logs.

entries.title: The Principle of Low-Failure-Load Design
entries.bodyHtml: Design so that when failures occur, human impact is contained. This principle motivates graceful degradation, care floors, and low irreversibility indices.

entries.title: The Reversibility Mandate
entries.bodyHtml: Critical actions must be undoable or paired with rollback lanes. The mandate aligns with time-to-restore targets and contestability.

entries.title: The Contestability Guarantee
entries.bodyHtml: People affected by system decisions can challenge, change, or overturn them—and win. Guarantees include wide permission surfaces, high appeal passage rates, and transparent design authority.
